thread.title: Elephants lovingly ‘kiss’ body of injured friend after it was shot dead | Metro News
thread.title_full: Elephants lovingly ‘kiss’ body of injured friend after it was shot dead | Metro News

author: Jen Mills For Metro.Co.Uk
title: Elephants lovingly ‘kiss’ body of injured friend after it was shot dead | Metro News
text:
Jen Mills for Metro.co.uk Sunday 19 Feb 2017 3:41 pm 
Incredible footage shows elephants refusing to leave the body of their friend, after it had been set upon by hyenas. 
They were filmed lovingly stroking the body of the dead elephant, which was shot dead by rangers when it broke its leg and had to be put down. 
Filmed at the Chobe National Park in Botswana, it has been seen as evidence of how strongly the huge mammals feel affection and loyalty to one another. 
One of the elephants strokes the body with its trunk, as if to kiss it. 
Lions, hyenas and jackals had already found the dead elephant and started to feed on it, but the herd of elephants stood guard to prevent any of them approaching its remains again. To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video (Picture: Storyful/Tracking the Wild) (Picture: Storyful/Tracking the Wild) (Picture: Storyful/Tracking the Wild) 
The footage was taken by Tracking the Wild, and also shows the elephant flapping its ears as if to cool it down. Studies have shown in the past that elephants could be capable of empathy. They have been seen to babysit other parents’ calves, protect and comfort others and help others that have been finding it difficult to move. More
